Skip this wanna be location and head to Memphis Minnie's on Haight, a real BBQ joint, which has amazing food and even more amazingly welcoming people and service.
author: Lem B.

description:
Very good BBQ. The homemade sauces are a real gem, the service is cheerful and fun, and they have a good beer selection. 

I find dining in is better then their take away.
author: PB S.

description: Our office catered from here today. What a feast we had... ribs, chicken, pulled pork... nice sides (mac n' cheese, cole slaw, greens). The BBQ sauce is pretty good too.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
My service was beyond excellent.  Perhaps they're listening to their feedback in this regard.  Food itself might be slow to cook -- what do you expect?

I had a half-rack of baby-back ribs.  They were more tender and less dry than Memphis Minnies.  The sauces aren't as varied as Minnie's. There's no equivalent for that yummy mustard BBQ sauce.  I also prefer Minnie's collard greens, although they're a bit of an acquired taste.  But the ribs are better at Baby Blues, and they at least have pulled pork on the menu.  Yeehaw!
author: Ben C.

description: I like their barbecue but they really have to learn to not burn the food and call it barbecue. I ordered blackened catfish and it was burnt catfish. They have a tendency to burn their chicken as well and it takes away from the flavor. Blackened does not mean burned and barbecue does not mean burned. The sauces are good and I wouldn't be able to eat the meat without it because they keep burning everything. That is my main complaint. The mac and cheese tastes good but it is really watery and not thick like it should be. Overall I actually like this place but I think people who get burnt food should send it back, (like I didn't do because they are so nice), in order to teach them the difference between burnt food and barbecued and seasoned food. If they could get that together then they would be okay because the food is actually pretty good. It just takes away from the meal when the meat is all burned up like that. I will be going back and hopefully they will change this way of cooking their food.
author: R. W.

description:
BB is almost like our living room, not only because of its proximity to our apt but also because we have been eating there often.  

What I like:
Baby back ribs, the ginger rib sauce, and for sides: creamed spinach, okra, and mac n' cheese.  The atmosphere is family-oriented in the early evening and changes to a friendly local bar into the night.  Also, the owner is often around and very welcoming.  

What could improve:
One time (out of 15?) our take-out order was botched and it took them a while to fix it, but it was the week of the World Series and BB was full of game watchers, so I forgave them.  Another time we ordered a larger-boned rib they had on special (per the owner's suggestion) and it was incredibly fatty, so now we stick to our favorites.
author: erin h.

description: 5 stars for some of the best hot dang BBQ/brisket I have had in a long time!  They do the brisket their own way - similar to a pulled pork sort of thing.  Creamed spinach was different than the usual too - more of a fresh spinach in light cream.  Mashed potatoes rocked.  Minus 1 star for prices being on the high side (especially when accounting for table service).
author: Kurosh H.

description:
Received an ambiguous update from a friend that there was good BBQ around my neighborhood, but had to call to actually get the name.  It was kind of iffy, considering the french accent of the girl that took our take-out order, but once we got this home (mashed, mac'n'cheese, pork, and some baby-back ribs, and we got some rolls also), all doubts were assuaged, because this was pretty frickin' good.  Didn't even have enough time to finish a beer before our food was ready to go.  I'll be adding this to my regular comfort-food too-lazy-to-cook cycle.

The included generic, unbranded wet naps had a pleasant lemony sent, and weren't soapy.
author: Andy B.

description:
Walking in here, we weren't greeted but walked straight to a table and seated ourselves. From that I was thinking, "ugh,great another place that's rude". But right when we sat down, the owner (not sure about that) but he seemed to be, came and greeted us & handed us menu's.

Okay so on to the food: Happy that they offer Lunch Specials Mon-Sun, but they didn't seem the best deal. We ordered: The Lakers Burger: this has bacon, blue cheese and dijon berry in it. My bf loooooved it and the owner said his brother makes the sauce to go with it. 

I had "The Hound dog": this was really good. I chose greens as my side (like always) i'm a huuuuge fan of greens, if the place serves greens, i'll try them. Plus I make some bomb-ass greens! they're good for you!! anyways, the greens were real good,not thee best i had. but the Cornbread was delicious!! you can taste small pieces of corn in it. The Beef Brisket was semi-good. I didn't finish it. Something about the sauce I didn't like. Everything had some type of spicyness to it. Cornbread had some jalapeno, beans had jalapenos and the greens were spicy. But it was that perfect spicyness, not overwhelming at all.

The service was great. The place wasn't empty but wasn't busy. The cooks were real nice and attentive. Also, they gave great tips on how to eat the food and with what sauces. Plus, the food was very fresh.

I would come here again. I seen they had Smoked CHicken wings, so I gotta try those.
Thanks BB BBQ!
author: Sarina I.

description: Very good BBQ and friendly staff. Good for food and game.
author: Kevin G.

description: Love this place! Their hot sauces are the best and you have to get the banana cream pudding.
author: E H.

description: Very cool space and a great friendly vibe.  I had baby backs and a beef rib.  They were OK, but the side were lights out.  The best cole slaw I've had, awesome mac n cheese, and I loved the okra. I'll go back with the family and friends.
author: Bryon W.

description:
Hot DAMN! This shit is gooooood-eatin', y'all!  

Finaaaally this Tennessee girl has found herself some spicy authentic BBQ! You know they know what they're doing when they serve the cole slaw ON the sandwich & have (3) kinds of BBQ sauce from mild & tangy to tongue-steamin' goodness.

The super tender pulled pork sandwich with a cold beer- mmm, mm good. All ya need is some SEC football, a screened in porch & I'm back home again. :-) Sigh.
author: Jamie R.

description: This place is super awesome! Me and the fiancé were trying for low carb and we were able to stick to it. We got pulled pork, Louisiana hotlinks, "Dillon" meatballs, okra and creamed spinach. All very delicious. We decided better than any bbq we've been to in Seattle. The ambiance is great- classic country, beers, super great staff (we had Holly- she rocks!). No wait! Go here! We will be coming back!
author: Hillary L.

description:
I'm on a constant lookout for pulled pork and theirs is the best I've had in SF...complimented perfectly by the different types of hot sauce (infused with yellow bell peppers!?!) and coleslaw on the side. My BF got a sausage sandwich, mac and cheese and mashed potatoes. 

The ambiance in Baby Blues is warm and welcoming, and we sat there for over an hour drinking beers and wallowing in deliciousness. 

Our server (John I think) was friendly and helpful...and a BBQ aficionado, of course.
author: carrie c.

description: This place is very yummy, reasonably priced, and right across the street from el rio. the brisket and the catfish sandwich are delicious. the atmosphere is chill. decor is outside bbq-ish.
author: Mia M.

description: DELICIOUS! We both had the pulled pork sandwich with mac & cheese, which was really good. Bread is fresh. All the sauces looked good, we went with one of the molds, which went well with the pork. Fun and clean atmosphere.
author: Jerylyn A.

description:
I have been craving good BBQ, which is a tough thing to find in SF.  For whatever reason, this city is so fixated on non-meat or new age options that it forgets the value in the simple act of cooking a piece of dead animal over an flame.  Cavemen (and cavewomen) certainly hit on a good thing when they first started doing it with mammoth and such, why not continue with what works?

Previously, I had by recommended to try Memphis Minnie's, which I was told had good BBQ.  It doesn't.  It has awful BBQ.  The meat is dry, but not because it has been spice-rubbed and smoked for several hours at low heat.  It is dry because it was cooked over a gas for not too much time and barely basted in mediocre sauce.  It isn't 'northern/Kansas' style and it isn't 'southern/Memphis' style.  It is bad.

Baby Blues is different.  While it would never be considered world class BBQ, it is the best BBQ I've ever had in California by a good margin.  The half slab I got was well seasoned and prepared. In the vein of Charlie Vergo's Rondezvous in Memphis, the ribs were somewhere between total dry rub and dripping is sauce.  They hung onto the bone, but had a nice tomato-based sauce that had been slow cooked on.  The bottled sauces were good and simple as well, mainly a thin BBQ sauce of the tomato and spices variety, and two hot sauces.

Service was a little slow, which would be the one downside, but the prices were fair.  My half slab was $11, a full slab is $21.  With two sides and corn bread you're looking at $18.  I'll definitely be going back, next time for pulled pork or maybe beef brisket.  Mmm do I love BBQ and I am glad I have finally found a place the is halfway decent at doing it here!
author: Eric M.

description: the first time i went here i was not much of a fan.....but, because of friends i have been back several times and it has really grown on me.  The must haves are the prawns, the ribs and there is this huge brontasaurus rib...I don't know what it's called but it's amazing!  We went there last night and had such a great time.  I even brought my 6 month old and they were super accomodating...she had a great time too, but then again...she likes to party.
author: LuLu M.

description:
I grew up on sweet tea. It was as common as breathing. Summers on Granny's porch helping her shuck corn from her garden or destring some beans were often cooled down with tall, sweaty glasses of iced tea sweetened with plenty of sugar. Little soothes the sweat of sweltering Southern summers like sweet, sweet tea.

Baby Blues BBQ has sweet tea. And it's exactly like the elixir I remember from my youth.

The boyfriend and I went here one Friday night for a date. We'd ordered takeout from them a couple of times before, but this was our first dine-in experience. And it rocked.

We didn't have to wait long at all for a table, and the hostess was quick and competent. Our server was attentive, energetic and as friendly as a waitress out to be at a BBQ joint. San Francisco is a foodie town where far too often the servers slack off because the food carries so much weight. And it kinda sucks; they sometimes act like you are doing them a favor by chosing to dine there. This server was a gem, though. No pretense, prompt and most importantly of all, attentive. (I watched the owner walk an older male guest through his beer order when he ordered a Coors that they did not carry.) You can tell the staff here really wants to get it right, and it makes all the difference.

The food is a little pricey, but man, is it good. Stick with the ribs and pulled pork, and you won't go wrong. We split the three meat, two side combo with cornbread, and we were both stuffed to the gills. 

It's a little noisy in here, but it's so great to see families, elderly couples, large groups, college dudes and couples all getting down on some country cooking. You get to steal away from San Francisco a little bit when you hit up this joint. It's not exactly Tennessee or Texas, but order the sweet tea and see if you don't forget that for a minute.
author: Brittney G.

description: Yummy!! Great neighborhood spot.  Parking is tricky, but it is worth the effort!  Personal faves are the pulled pork and the creamed spinach.  Totally yummy comfort food.  Plus the staff is super nice and welcoming.  And they have a great beer selection!
author: Marin G.

description:
OMG NOM NOM BBQ

I really enjoyed this BBQ place.  Specializing in a North Carolina style BBQ (Maybe. What do I know? I'm from Florida.), they make a serious roasted rib.  (It's not the pink ring style.) Both the Memphis (regular) pork ribs and the baby back ribs were toothsome.  I also enjoyed the surprising but tasty renditions of collard greens and moist corn bread.  

I split one of the large ($24) plates with a friend and we were both dead afterward.  I wished I could have had the the Mac N Cheese, but I was with someone keeping kosher for Passover.  That's right, the way she keeps Kosher for Passover is eating pork ribs with sweet potatoes.  That's how we Jews roll.

They also have a few spicy-ass sauces.  I prefered the sweet one, which had kick too.  Oh, and if you're a vegan, stay far away!
author: Daniel S.

description:
I just spent the last three days in bed with a cold. It let me catch up on some reading and movie watching. The one outstanding moment was re-watching Coal Miner's Daughter. Damn, it's a good movie.

I'm too young to remember Loretta Lynn and her music but she is a very intriguing success story. She marries this coal miner named 'Dew' and they embark on an adventure which eventually leads to her becoming the top country music singer in the entire United States of America. I know I sound like 'Forest Gump' right now. Please forgive.

When I think about coal miner's daughter, I think about BBQ. Luckily, I have Baby Blues BBQ in the mission. It is the BEST bbq restaurant in the city. It's not even close.

Sissy Spacek sings a signature song which states, "I'm proud to be a coal miner's daughter..."  Well, I'm a first generation immigrant from Vietnam. I'm proud to be a "first immigrant son of a engineer's son."

The country singing is in progress...

5 stars.
author: John T.

description: The Texas Beef rib w/ pork and beans and crack and cheese...Wow and the owner is good people which in my book is make or break..
author: Sherman L.

description:
Save your money. Seriously.

And if you don't choose to heed my advice, I suggest you take a spit shield and boxing gloves with you because apparently the owner likes to get wasted and scream at his employees. 

We brought an out of town friend here, and while he brushed off the fact that his Side Car had someone's hair in it and was cold, it didn't help that the owner was giving him sleazy looks the entire time we were there...and we're gonna just assume it wasn't because he's gay. 

But like 45 minutes later, he proceeded to get in to an obviously gay employees face and literally SPIT in her face and fire her in front of the entire restaurant. One little girl even started crying and employees had to intervene because he was scaring customers. 

I have to say our experience there was scary, at best. Just be careful if you go. And stay clear of the owner if you're gay.
author: Kristin H.

description:
I'm no barbecue expert.  Where I grew up, everyone wore shoes to school.  Kidding!  But, Cali palate aside, here's what I like about this place:  They serve Kool-Aid.  The menu includes things like The Suicide King and the Get Down Miss Brown.  What are they?  Doesn't matter.  The names are cool as hell.  And they will deliver macaroni and cheese to my house.  

Here's what I didn't like:  The key lime pie was definitely a Jell-O mix slopped into a pre-made graham cracker crust.  Served at my grandma's house?  Cute.  For $5 a slice? Jive.
author: Rosie W.

description:
Having grown up in east Texas, and being a huge fan of real slow-smoked BBQ, I've seen a few legitimate BBQ joints in my day.  Unfortunately, this isn't one of them.  There is nothing authenticly BBQ about this place.  That's not to say that the food's not good.  It can be, depending on what you order.  The best thing I've had is the shrimp po-boy, which is delicious.  The hamburger is also excellent -- they mix gorgonzola and bacon into the meet while pattying it, then grill it perfectly with a cruchy exterior and juicy interior.  The buns are particularly good.  
The sweet tea, made with brown sugar, is also a nice twist.  On these items alone, they earn 3 stars.  This is a good meal.

But that ain't real BBQ.  It takes more than frozen shrimp, hamburger, and sweet tea to call yourself an authentic BBQ joint.  That's especially true considering that the more traditional BBQ items I've tried havn't been all that good.  The pulled pork, chicken, and brisket were all dry and not very tasty.  They needed tons of the housemade XXX sauce (which was nice and spicy) to give them any flavor.  The collard greens were an odd grey/greenish color and were flavorless and watery.  And whoever calls this the best mac-and-cheese of their life is, well, clearly not from the South.  This mac-and-cheese was nasty and curdled and the elbow macaronis are way over-cooked and mushy.  I've tried it twice now to be sure, and I sent it back the second time it was so bad.  

Go for the burger or the po-boy...and get some sweet tea...then walk over to Humphrey Slocumbe for some outrageous small batch ice cream!
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I didn't realize I arrived at Baby Blues BBQ until my friend walked in the door because of the "DRUGS" sign above the establishment. Looking around, I noticed a couple of divey bars and a flamboyant club across the street. Once I walked in, the 50s inspired decor seemed as funky as its exterior. 

Once seated, I ordered the beef brisket with mac n cheese and collard greens. My friend ordered the pulled pork with potato salad and baked beans. We were immediately served, not even 5 minutes passed before our plates were placed in front of us. It was a Monday so there weren't many others in the restaurant. 

I thoroughly enjoyed the baked beans, it was topped with a heap of pulled pork and full of flavor. Their BBQ sauce and beef brisket are quite satisfying, but I was incredibly disappointed with the collard greens and unimpressed by the mac n cheese and potato salad. The collard greens were cooked in some kind of salty tomato stew and was nothing like southern collard greens. Mac n cheese had a great texture but the flavor was lacking. 

Decent food, but it feels more like someone wanted to make a BBQ place their way instead of how it should really be.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
One of the times I ate here (well, had it delivered), my chicken was so undercooked that it was pinkish-purplish inside, which scared me a bit. The other time, it was just as flavorless, but beige-pink instead of purple. The brisket is pretty dry, as well.

Lackluster sides, watery and vinegar-rich sauce, flavorless meat. It ain't BBQ if it's oven-cooked, folks. There's no meaty smokiness to any of their dishes. I know that everyone talks about how their cornbread is "how cornbread is supposed to be", but it's a tad undercooked IMHO and uses WAY too much oil. 

If you're looking for BBQ, go for Big Nate's or... well... ANYWHERE but this place! It's too late for me - save yourself!!!

Not a fan at all. Will not ingest again.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Baby Blue's Ribs are definitely something you want to eat. Unless you're a vegetarian.  Mack and cheese is a side you want to have on the plate.  The collard greens were good.  They make their own BBQ sauces, three to choose from, and all are unique.

The fish was pretty good.  If you don't like char from the grill you might not like this so much.

Now I could make another song about BB BBQ, but I am too hungry now to even bother.

=======================================

Baby Blues, you got what I need but you say they're just a friend
And you say they're just a friend, oh Baby Blues
You, you got what I need but you say they're just a friend
But you say they're just a friend, oh Baby Blues
You, you got what I need but you say they're just a friend
But you say they're just a friend

Dam Baby Blues you are whoring yourself out because you have so many people visiting.  Dam your BBQ is good.  And your XXX sauce.... BOOYAH!  The pulled pork was tender and flavorful, red beans and rice, delicious, mac & cheese a bit on the runny side, and the corn bread was out of this world.  Service was friendly and prompt.

Baby Blues, you got what I need.
author: Po L.

description:
I give this place 5 stars in its class - I used to frequent memphis minnies which frankly now has gone downhill.  Prices up, portions down, bah humbug.

Enter 6 people on Friday night drinking at El Rio - "LETS GET BBQ"

We wandered across the street to the giant sign that reads DRUGS over this place and ordered a package deal for 6 which included enough food for easily 10 people. pulled pork, brisket, and a ton of sides- 

lets do the list

sweet potatoes - syrupy and delicious, 
collard greens - best ive had, hands down - with little chunks of bacon and a good smokey flavor
the coleslaw - perfect
the mac and cheese - pretty damn good, not the best I've ever had but pretty damn good
the okra - +1 for even having it on the menu - delicious
the baby back ribs - fall of the bone goodness
the pulled pork - generous portion, tender, yummy
the beef brisket - holy shit, this was my favorite, i could have eaten it all myself.
creamed spinach - that's the only on the menu that didn't wow me.  It wasn't bad, just nothing special.

We left there with guts busted and happy faces with a GIANT bag of leftovers enough to feed our hangovers all saturday and sunday.  If only my wife hadn't forgotten them at the bar.   Doh !!

Seriously though, this place rocks, and the waitresses and the staff is super friendly (and pretty cute too)  

GO GO GO
author: Rick R.

description: As far as BBQ in the city, this is top of my list.  Perfectly prepared dishes, amazing sides and homemade sweet tea!  I got the ribs and  chicken, just delicious.  They also provide a range or BBQ sauces for you to pair with your meal, all of which I'm pretty sure are made in-house. They also have a great selection of beers on tap.  Cornbread, YES!
author: Louis C.

description:
the food is really good here. i usually get the brisket. 
but last time i went i got a brisket sandwich and 2 sides. it was $19!
how do you justify these prices?
author: Matthew R.

description:
O.k so my frienda know how much I love ribs
So they took me last weekend to this place and order for me the taxass rib and I have to say wow.....
I got a plate with real big rib cooked the same way I asked for
And after I test it I knew why my freinds took me over there
The rib was great also the service and the place designef realy nice
Anyway I hige recommend this place and realy think you shuld go tray it
And after that you can,thank me...
author: Jhon S.

description: The sides are so-so, but the BBQ itself is just ridiculously good!
author: Ramon F.

description: this place does smell good, but so do most bbq spots. the chairs are a little uncomfortable but that's not the biggest problem. the Memphis ribs were ok and so was the chicken,but everything else sucked i had the baked beans (yuck) the waitress suggested the mac &cheese and that was nothing special. she made the chicken rice sound off the hook, but all they did was make it with chicken broth instead of straight water. Im trying sneakys bbq  down the street next time. will let you know. i also did not see sliced beef which i love.
author: Sean W.

description: Some of the best food in San Francisco!  A little pricey, but well worth it.
author: Megan T.

description: Baby Blues claims to be a BBQ place.  I've only been once.  The bbq brisket, a staple in most bbq joints, was not smoked at all.  It was like pulled beef in a sauce.  That would get you shot in Texas.  And you would be acquitted.  There's a lot of BBQ poseurs in the world.  I don't know about the rest of the menu but go to Sneaky's or Memphis Minnie's if you're looking for smoked, brisket.  A lot of people wouldn't know authentic bbq if it hit them in the mouth. I'll get off my soap box now.  Sneaky's BBQ inside the Rebel bar on Market @ Valencia is my new hero.  Brisket and Kurobota pork belly to die for.
author: gary l.

description:
I am about to do you all a very BIG favor. 

Save yourself the trouble and DO NOT EAT HERE. 

I went here tonight with a friend, and we were really looking forward to it. I did bring some home the other night, but only the sides. 

We sat at the bar since there would be about a 20-30 minute wait for a table. I was set on having the Baby Back ribs. They were out, until 7:00. They were also out of the "long bone" spare ribs. What kind of BBQ place runs out of ribs?! Disappointed, I settled on the Pulled Pork Platter. We also ordered an appetizer to get us going. That was OK ... the only choice is pork, chicken, or shrimp on corn bread, served open face with cole slaw. 

But before we get our appetizer, we get a chicken sandwich we didn't order. Turns out it was for somebody else at the bar. 

Forty Five minutes later, still no entree for either of us. A couple seated next to us ordered basically the same thing, but different sides, AND seated long after us, got their food first. What the hell is that?! We start to get annoyed, as take out bags were flying out the door, and more people seated after us got their food. We asked for our food, got no response, other than befuddled looks from the servers. The guy behind the counter completely ignored our requests, hand waves, etc. 

We ended up leaving having just the appetizer. We didn't even wait for the bill but out of the goodness of my heart, I left a $20 with a note telling whoever cared to read it that no food is worth that wait. 

DEFINITELY WILL NOT GO BACK. Neither should you.
author: Michael M.

description:
This place is a roller coaster of emotions!

There was the high I felt when I found out a honest to goodness BBQ place was opening blocks away from my house.

There was the low I felt when I would walk by the storefront for many weeks only to see that the place wasn't yet open.

There was the joy of seeing the first reviews proving the place had opened, dampened by the mix of praise and complaint.

By the time I finally got to eat at this place, I didn't know what to expect.  The food was excellent.  Best ribs I've had in quite some time.  Brisket was not was I expected; it was more like pulled pork than the slab type brisket I've had in the past and it needed lots of additional hot sauce.  The sides, however, were amazing.  I could eat the cole slaw every day, and the corn bread is worth waiting for.

The service was a bit slow as they seemed to be short handed on a Sunday afternoon.  Prices were pretty steep.  But definitely the best BBQ I've had so far in SF.

This is one of the few places I'll miss when I move from my current place.
author: Zhi Q.

description: Great BBQ.  Good food, good sized portions, a bit pricey for some dishes.  Excellent service and rustic  atmosphere.
author: Random R.

description:
This place ain't too bad, been here once on a weekend food run.  Felt the urge to eat some bbq and this was the closest bby joint by my hood.  Even though I've only been here once my food experience was a positive one.  Obviously I'd have to go there more than once and check out the other items on the menu.  

But all in all if you are down by the Mission and Cesar chavez street area and you are feenin for Mexican food, Phat Philly that are close by that area then roll down here for some bbq.
author: marcus o.

description:
A friend suggested we come here for lunch and indeed I will be returning. 
Started out with some meatballs for appetizers, and woah were them balls good! Definitely peaked my interest to order a burger next time around. The lingonberry sauce, was a perfect compliment to them. 
For my meal I ordered the beef brisket sandwich with a side of mac and cheese. The meat was shredded, placed on ciabatta bun, topped with coleslaw. I preceded to add a little spicy olive oil, and the garlic-ky bbq sauce. Mmm, mmm, so good. Had to cut it in half to prevent it from getting everywhere, but I finished that bad boy off. As for that mac and cheese, I'm a tough critic and I'll have to admit I didn't leave any behind. Although I ordered the beef brisket. my friends enjoyed a shrimp po'boy, and a pulled pork sandwich. Needless to say we left stuffed, happy, and fans of this old-school drug store turned restaurant. 
Definitely need to try their blackened catfish po'boy, amongst others. They've got plenty of favorites on tap (anchor steam) and some delicious desserts on the menu such as apple pie, peach cobbler, and banana pudding. Hey and if you like this place you can even grab a t-shirt to go (;
author: Valerie C.

description:
Came here with 4 of my buddies so 5 total, it was packed so we sat at the bar.

we should've ordered the set meal for $110 which feeds i think 6 people. 
we ended up ordering seperate entrees and it came out to 140 including tip.

portions were decent, came with two sides i choose smoked ribs and 2 sides of okra.

my friends ordered the brisket, which was shreds of meat, the taste was ok but  was expecting it not to be like pulled pork.

ordered the okra it was too sour so i didnt like it
also ordred the smoked baby back, it was too burnt so after the chared part there was some tender meat to munch on.
mac and cheese noodles were over cooked which was ok but there was like some kinda of bread in it or something kinda different for me
Service was slow took awhile for the waitress to take our order.
food took awhile to come

i gave them an extra star cuz

the collard greens were tasty, little sour but bearable
the hot sauce was good
free drink refills

I will not be coming back :(
author: DOM d.

description: IN MY MOUTH.  This place is truly awesome.  Service is always fast & efficient, the BBQ is by far the best I've had in the city.  Be sure to experiment with the selection of incredible sauces all over your pork ribs.  If you're a country boy like me, this is your home away from home.. (without the left wing politics of coarse)  I can't wait to come again, thanks for being awesome Baby Blues staff, see you soon!
author: Kyle H.

description:
Baby Blues BBQ catered our annual company BBQ this year (150 attendees) and knocked it out of the park! Paul and his team were an absolute pleasure to deal with and the food was fresh and delicious.

He did an on-site BBQ with chicken, brisket, pulled pork, portabella mushrooms, hot dogs, corn, garden salad, and coleslaw. He also arranged for all the rental equipment including tables, chairs, wine glasses, and linens. All for a super reasonable price.

I would definitely recommend using Baby Blues BBQ for your next event!
author: Kevin K.

description:
This place was unfortunately disappointing.  First of all to call it BBQ is not accurate since the meat is not actually BBQed.  Cooking the meat in the oven is not the same as BBQ.  The pulled pork had a good, tender, and juicy texture, but the flavor was rather bland since it wasn't smoked and therefore didn't have any smokey flavor.  The same goes for the ribs.

Of the fixin's we had, the cole slaw and mac and cheese were really good. The collards tasted like sweet and sour cabbage. They were cooked in some kind of tomato-based sauce and left my North Carolina bred husband very confused and disappointed.  The baked beans were also a bit disappointing since they had like 5 different kind of beans including black beans, which do not belong in baked beans.  The flavor of the baked beans was good, but the competing texture of all of those beans didn't help.  I was not crazy about the cornbread and found it to be a bit overcooked. I like the whole corn kernels in there and the flavor was pretty good, but again it was overcooked.

I had the peach betty for dessert and I liked it, but my husband thought it was too heavy on the nutmeg.  After, I wished I had tried the banana pudding.

This is one of the few places you can find sweet tea in the city, but frankly, it wasn't sweet enough.

If you have been to the south and know what BBQ tastes like down there, this place doesn't cut it.  With some of the other places in the city, I don't think we'll be going there again.
author: Nicole W.

description:
All I can say is WOW!  Just got home from stuffing my face with some really amazing BBQ!  I've not had a lot of great experiences in SF BBQ cuisine, but this joint just blew my mind!  

Atmosphere is unassuming, even diner-esque... walk in say hello sit down and order.  In fact, I was expecting mediocre service and food, even though the place was immaculately clean and clearly well taken care of ... boy was I surprised when the owner's daughter was my waitress!  She knew her food, drinks and her condiments well,  and was as friendly as one could hope.

About 45 minutes into a fan-friggin-tastic meal the owner plopped down next to me to have a rib or 3 for dinner and ask me how I was liking everything.  Just seeing how much this man LOVED his restaurant and genuinely cared about the dining experience his customers were having makes me all warm and fuzzy!

My friend and I spent a modest (under $70 total) amount on dinner and I have a fridge full of left overs and a promise to go back for more!  

My southern Mama is going to fall over when she has the sweet potato mash, the pork and beans or the Memphis Ribs!
author: Jason H.

description:
The drinks are great.  Yummy lemonade, Kool-Aid, Blue Moon.  That's about where the positives end.

We walked in on a Wednesday around 9:00pm.  Still semi-crowded but not bad.  Plenty of open seating but they seemed to have a heck of a time trying to figure out where to put us.  

Food:  I ordered a hamburger, well-done.  "Just no pink inside," is what I say.  It arrives and there is a charcoal crust, nearly a quarter-inch deep on all surfaces.  I decide to be brave and take a bite.  It was like eating a brick from the walls of Hell.  I'm not one to complain or send back food--I'm too shy and embarassed.  But this?  I just couldn't do it.

I call the waiter over, who takes the plate.  The manager comes back, with the plate in hand and says something to the effect of:  "You ordered this well done.  If you want it cooked through, the fire is going to char it.  It's always going to be this way."  There I am, with my plate shoved in my face, hamburger sitting there with one bite taken out of it, and thinking to myself, "I would be embarassed to serve this."  I simply tell her again that it is inedible but I would be happy to try something else from their menu.

Beef brisket sandwich comes.  It's ok.  Nothing to write home about.  Which was the guys' impression of their chicken, pork, and ribs.  Mashed potatoes were way too chunky and came out cold--it was like eating potato salad.  The mac&cheese wasn't bad though.

Pricey.  Bill came out to $30/pp, with each guy only getting 1 beer and then my lemonade.  I think that's steep for BBQ, especially that far down on Mission Street.  Oh yea, and that $30/pp was after we had them re-total the check because they charged us for extra beers never ordered.

Sure, it may have been just that I was hungry coming in the door that they seemed slow.  And anyone can write down extra drinks by accident.  But do not shove a plate in my face that I've had to send back!  Final straw and not going back.
author: Melissa Q.

description:
The huge DRUGS sign overhead is fitting, as this place is addictive.

The 'Mason Dixon' was perfect. I prefer dry rubbed, but the sticky, tangy char on these ribs may convert me yet. Each succulent rib pulled clean off the bone, and the sauce doesn't stick to your teeth. The chicken was just as good, with a lighter dose of sauce to balance the milder flavor. Both the mashed sweets and mac n' cheese were nice compliments.

The cornbread is worth special mention. It is more dense and cake-like than the more crumbly variety found elsewhere. It almost deserves a spot on the dessert menu.

Dessert. We ordered Pecan Pie and a Peach Betty. Sadly, by the time I arrived for pick up, they'd run out of the Peach Betty. Sensing my disappointment and indifference to substitution of Banana Pudding, the owner graciously served up two desserts to go with the sweet Pecan Pie, free of charge!

A generous slice of moist Chocolate Kahlua Cake and two servings of their homemade Banana Pudding went home with me. One bite of the Banana Pudding and I knew why he was so proud of it. It is Phenomenal,  with a mellow banana flavor in a rich consistency somewhere between a dense mousse and buttercream. Sin with Nilla Wafers. Half a serving and I was staring at the ceiling in bliss.

Like the junkiemaker says, "The first one's free..."

Note: If picking up, bring a wingman to right-turn circle the block for your getaway since traffic routing on that end of Precita is crazy cryptic.
author: Andy R.

description: Ok, so this place inspired me to write a review just because the food was that bad. I wish i would have known before I spent $40 on food that I ended up waisting. Don't get me wrong the service there is great the people are very nice but for the prices that they are the food taste like it had come straight out of a can, for example I ordered the beef brisket and pulled pork with a side of baked beans and corn bread, the baked beans were bland and really had no flavor, the pulled pork was ok but it was pretty cold and the portion was ridiculously small and my brisket looked like the pulled pork, it wasn't sliced like it says on the menu, that was cold too...and last the corn bread, i love corn bread and I was looking forward to eating at least!! some good ol corn bread but When I seen the corn bread it was a small square about 3x3 inches small and it was mushy like a bread pudding with nuts and little pieces of corn, super hipster corn bread, and the flavor was sorry to say but.. gross!. I will never eat there again and thats too bad because the place is nice and convenient, nicely presented but I was definitely not satisfied with the food. It's not your good old fashion barbecue spot, it's very modern with hipstery flavors to it and thats just not my flavor. Booo ;(
author: Christine A.

description:
Yum, Yum, yum, yum, yum, yum yum.   
I love the meat.  I love the sauces.  I love the long wooden table.  I have been there for a large birthday party, and several times with just the family; and, had great meals every time.  Also, it is a great place to take a toddler / preschooler because of the noise and activity levels.  

The only thing that would make this place better is offering Whiskey!
author: Francis B.

description: Great service food is really good and the chicken sandwich is the best one I ever had
author: Pete H.

description:
Solid, solid, solid. All around solid.

I was never a fan of BBQ which has a char-broiled finish to it. I wouldn't say I am now convert, but I can say that I am happy to look the other way with Baby Blues' ribs. Meat falling off the bones and dry rub flavor shines through the char-broil. Standard barbeque sauce on the table was flavorful without overpowering (tomato-based with a hint of vinegar.)

Wide variety of well executed sides including mashed sweet potatoes, baked beans, mac and cheese and collard greens. The waiter mentioned something about the cole slaw having wasabi undertones, but I wish I didn't hear that. I would rather live my fantasy of the perfect, TRADITIONAL, barbeque outside of the likes of Memphis or the Carolinas. Mac and cheese seemed to have spices that added character as well, but it would have worked for me without the complexity.

They have both world-class beers on tap and distinctive but cost-effective wines by the glass. They had me at the German pils and Argentinean malbec. They even had Kool-Ade for the kids.

Desserts including pecan pie and bread pudding looked great but I didn't  have room.

Some purists would say that the atmosphere, menu etal. is too high brow for an authentic BBQ joint. I tend to agree, but the place is good at resetting expectations and having customers leave satisfied.

They might have a sign somewhere outside, but I didn't see it. I just followed my GPS to the street address. Additional confusion stems from their converting an old drug store with Rexall sign in tact. When I was there for lunch on MLK day, I found ample parking near by on Mission as well as on the side street.
author: David P.

description:
2 of us ate on Thus. 7/9/2009 @ 7:15pm. 

They said parking at the Blockbuster, only there was SIGNS & there was tow away signs...so we had to find street parking...  There was NO sign we saw only 2 big saying DRUGS (historic) ...It was a difficult place to find...    

I had the "Pulled Pork Plate" a friend had the "Ace in the Sleeve" (ribs, shrimp & catfish) 

It was VERY BIG portions!! That was fine with me! We ended up getting the mild BBQ sauce- the other 2 on the table were way too hot for us. 

I didn't know until we started eating that we were right next the VERY LOUD music!! We end up not taking much during our meal.... The hostess should have warned us music was about to start ahead of time.  

We ended paying under $60. including tip with only iced tea to drink & no dessert. When we asked for a menu, they said there was none, when I asked again to another server - I was able to get one! When we sat down the cocktail waitress asked us if we wanted drinks- she didn't seem to understand anything we said. Guys were hauling paint 4 cans too!  I am handicapped & the stools were unstable...     

It was all all good until THAT NIGHT I HAD THE "RUNS" FOR 2 WHOLE DAYS!!  THE OTHER PERSON COMPLAINED ABOUT THE SAME THING - only less severe than mine. 

I DON''T RECOMMEND THIS AT ALL.     

Pete
author: Peter W.

description: Had the baby blue with pulled pork, brisket, and ribs. All nom with banana pudding to top it off. Def coming back to attack the rest of the menu. :)
author: Ray J.

description:
Don't waste your money! After reading the raved review in the local newspaper, I was excited to try this place, but VERY DISSAPPOINTED! I tried their baby back ribs and it's a bit dry, thought their "famous" BBQ sauce would help, nothing outstanding, a bottle of Bull's Eye would tasted better. I can actually BBQ a better ribs at home. Then, their pulled pork tasted like plain boiled pork, no taste to it. Tried 4 of their side dishes, the creamed spinach was runny, looked like they boiled the spinach and stirred in a cream sauce, no favor to it. Baked bean, mac n' cheese and collard greens, all flat with no taste, everything is just food. 

To add insult to injury, their prices are too expensive for the neighborhood and quality. Their portions are too small. Not worth it! Although, I am all for supporting local small restaurant, I will never return.
author: Anna W.

description:
It's some pretty good BBQ.  I like that they don't slather sauces on the meat.  Instead they have 5 different kinds of sauces you can dip your meat in.  You'll get a mix of hot, tangy, sweet - all good!

I shared the larger platter with one other person: Bones and No Bones: 1/2 Mesquite Ribs, pulled pork, cornbread, 2 fixins and 1 extra fixin.  It was PLENTY for 2 of us.  

Yummy Fixins: Okra (tangy with tomato and cooked perfectly), Mac n Cheese (not too cheesy and heavy), Cole Slaw (my favorite, light on the mayo, lots of celery seeds).  

My BIL had the Texas Ribs (the only beef ribs on the menu): tender and more fatty than the port ribs.  A LOT of meat plus the cornbread and 2 fixins.  Could be shared by 2 people.  

They were out of the strawberry shortcake but we tried the pear cobbler, not bad.  

Service was friendly, parking - not so friendly.  Get there early or you'll be circling for a while.
author: Grace K.

description: This place smokes and bbqs their meat. They are serious. The sauces are homemade and plentiful . I love the bbq chicken sandwich. We went with a group of 20 and had the combo for 14 people and ate till we were stuffed with an alcoholic drink it was only $20 a piece including tip. Its a ridiculously good place for family style eating, and you get to try everything that way. I have been vegan for my whole life and this is the place i chose to eat my first meat. i was not disappointed! For sides i liked the okra, stewed tomatoes, and baked beans...yummers! They are all vegan ...they also do a vegan combo plate named after the charming owner's sister...watch out for the tippy metal chairs at the big group table in the front...warning.
author: christie m.

description:
Ordered the Brisket sandwich lunch special.  Having not really looked at the menu and thinking that Brisket ought to be sliced, was really disappointed to find a meat jello mush on garlic bread.  The mac-n-cheese side I ordered was overcooked pasta in a cheese substance that more resembled cottage cheese than anything else.  

I should have known better when I saw the Filthadelphia sports paraphernalia all over the bar.
author: Joel M.

description:
Not the best and not the worst BBQ. I am very happy that Baby Blues BBQ has opened up in my hood and it might become a staple for take out, along with Goood Frickin' Chicken and El Gran Taco Loco (my current favs from the hood). 

I was excited to see this place open up and take over a location that has had nothing to offer for many years. Baby Blues is a very friendly, welcoming and cool place -  good for take out or to dine in and have a draft beer. 

I opted for take out and decided to order a lot of food (just for myself) and get a good feel for the place. I think it's reasonably priced for BBQ and the 3 meals have stretched into 6, so it's pretty generous portions. 

The Food:
1) "Memphis Queen"- 1/2 BABY BACK RIBS, 1/2 MEMPHIS RIBS $24.95. Not my favorite BBQ ribs. The rub was good, but there was no smoky flavor at all. The meat was tender enough, but because it lacked any smokiness it seemed like they were just baked. I might not order the ribs again, and that's a big minus. Isn't BBQ supposed to be smoked? I liked the Memphis Ribs better than the Baby Back Ribs. 

2) Beer braised BEEF BRISKET plate $13.95. I've never had pulled brisket before. Not what I was expecting, but I actually liked it a lot. Again, the meat is not smoked. I liked the brisket better than the ribs, and in general this is not usually my preference.

3) Marion County slow-smoked CHICKEN $14.95. Of all the meats, I liked the chicken the best. It had the most flavor and I would eat this on a semi-regular basis and it tasted the most of smoke. The portion was a half a chicken.

The Sides:
1) Baked Beans: were watery and more like a cross between bean soup and baked beans. I would not order these again. I have the best recipe for baked beans and I might give it to them. These might have been vegetarian, but I'm not sure. Not a good side - a little too boring. 

2) Coleslaw: OK, nothing special. I would not order this side again, since they have some sides that are fantastic.

3) Sauteed Okra: a grand slam. Not many places serve okra 'cause it's one of those challenging foods for people who didn't grow up with the stuff. I grew up eating okra (Southern parents) and I've never had it prepared like this before. Fucking awesome. It's sauteed with tomatoes and lots of vinegar. I loved this dish and hope they don't take it off the menu.

4) Mashed Sweet Potatoes: my other favorite. Simple and yummy. Much better for you than regular mashed potatoes.

5) Collard Greens: pretty good. I've never had collards done exactly like this, they weren't braised beyond recognition and had bacon and tomatoes in them. I would order this side again.

6) Chicken Smoked Rice: good, but really tasted just like Zatarains brand boxed yellow rice. I like the stuff, but it didn't taste homemade. A little junk foody, but sometimes junk foody is good. 

The BBQ Sauces: 
1) regular BBQ sauce: very vinegary. It's tangy and sweet and makes your mouth wake up. I usually like more molasses and a thicker consistency - I'm a big fan of the Big Nates' BBQ sauce. All and all, their sauce really grew on me - it has a lot of personality. 

2) Hot BBQ sauce: it's medium (not hot, just a little mouth burn) and also has a lot of personality. I feel the same way about it as I did their regular sauce - it grew on me too. 

Note: The corn bread is really yummy here. It's not traditional at all, but is almost like a cornmeal cake. It's got corn kernels and is very sticky. I loved it.

Summary:
Baby Blues BBQ gets a solid 3 stars from me. This place has it's own San Francisco Bernal Heights vibe and will do well. Next, I am looking forward to trying their BBQ seafood dishes.

Wishes:
I wish Baby Blues would add 2 side dishes to their menu: lima beans and braised cabbage and also use my spicy chipotle baked beans recipe.
author: Yvette K.

description:
The lunch meals are a good deal.  For under $15, you can stuff your face full of BBQ ribs, cornbread, and a side.  The sauces give it a nice kick of flavor and you'll be licking your finger tips because of all the sauce.  

Why did I give it 2 stars you ask?  It is nearly impossible to get any service from this place.  You basically have to seat yourself, get the menus yourself, and go up to the cashier to pay.

Even though the food is decent, I probably would not come here again because of the service.
author: Danny P.

description:
had the catfish po boy + mac and cheese lunch special.

the sandwich was on a small round bun,, had a thin piece of fish, and a skimpy lump of coleslaw on top.  just a lot smaller portion than expected esp given the high price.

mac and cheese was average.
author: Henry H.

description:
There's not a lot of good BBQ in the city, so Baby Blue certainly scratches an itch.

It's a fun place to grab a not-too-expensive meal, I really like the pulled pork sandwiches.The service has always been great and the place has a laid back, fun vibe.

I don't like the way they do their sides and the key lime pie was not good - but it's a BBQ place and the focus is tender, delicious meat, so I am not going hard on them.

I don't love it enough to head across town and find parking, but it's a great neighborhood choice for BBQ.
author: Krissy M.

description:
Eh, it was just ok.  We ordered the Memphis style ribs and pull pork.  I felt like it needed more seasoning or something.  The mac and cheese was just ok as well.

+1 for the extra friendly service.  They were on top of the drink refills.
author: Michelle T.

description:
This place is so weird it's awesome. There was some kind of hoedown going on when we walked in and the crowd was all riled up. The service was spectacular. We chatted it up with the hostess who actually gave me a hug after seeing us to our table. The waitress sat down with us to answer some of our questions and the owner came out to chat it up with us after our meal. Oh..and the waitress gave us a free sampling of all the desserts. How can you not love them?

Which brings me around to the food:
Minuses - The pork was ok and the beef shank was decent but not great. Of the desserts most were ok. 
Pluses - The short ribs. Oh my god. My mouth's starting to water just thinking about it. They were absolute heaven. If you like ribs you absolutely must try this place. Also the pecan pie is un-f*cking-unbelievable. 

Overall, the ambiance is fun and festive, the service is spectacular, and the food, while hit or miss, can be fantastic if you know what to order. Know that, and you're going to have a great night here. 

Glad to see this place up and running. Good luck guys!
author: Shreya C.

description:
This is a tricky review for me. I really really want to love this restaurant. 

The first time I went it was a busy night and the food was awesome.The ribs were delish the sides are amazing. The mac and cheese...SO good. Collard greens- Yum!

 I have been 3 times since and I have to say the dinner has never been as good as that first night. But I want it to be SO BADLY! I love BBQ, especially good BBQ. This is OK BBQ, but after meeting the owner I believe he will strive to be the best he can be. Working to never let a dry over cooked piece of meat leave the kitchen. 

I will keep trying, hoping for perfection.
author: Kent T.

description:
nnnnnnnnnDUDE! I was expecting some crap BBQ like you would find at safeway..pre cooked, burnt, not much flavor, but this place is the exact opposite of that.
I got a meal that had brisket (ALOT OF BRISKET) hot link, 2 sides and a soda for like $14 bucks and for the quality and amount fo food, I was expecting to pay at least $20. The sides was quite big, as I got the mashed sweet potatoes and cornbread. I asked for the meal to go, and it came in a tinfoil package which perfectly held everything in it's own compartments...very lucky too since the brisket is very juicy!

They also have an assortment of their own sauces which they put into to-go containers, as requested.

I am honestly trying to find something I didn't like, but so far, I couldn't. I'm going back soon, so if the place suddenly starts to suck, I will update
author: Nic K.

description:
Let me preface my thoughts by saying that I'm a real barbecue aficionado.  I have a mild obsession with good barbecue; in fact, I ordered the June 2008 issue of Texas Monthly (which ranks the best barbecue joints in Texas) and am going on a barbecue journey through rural Texas next month.  I realize Baby Blues bills itself as North Carolina barbecue, but I'm familiar enough with both styles to be able to write intelligently.

The problem with barbecue in San Francisco is that no restaurants are serious enough about the meat to use a pit smoker rather than one of those generic commercial smokers.  Notice that every well-regarded barbecue joint in the South pit smokes the barbecue.  Being a NC/TX barbecue snob when eating in CA isn't about putting on airs--there are real, tangible, substantive differences in the quality of the meat and the preparation.  Seeing the commercial smoker when I walked into Baby Blues was an immediate point against.

Now to the food.  Baby Blues has its strengths and weaknesses.  I compare it most directly to Memphis Minnie's, which I believe to be the only decent barbecue restaurant in the city (Bo's in Lafayette is good but quite a drive).  I don't think Baby Blues compares favorably to Minnie's.  The brisket (braised--most serious barbecue restaurants serve it sliced) is absolutely drenched in sauce.  Good brisket doesn't need to be served in a soup of barbecue sauce.  Makes it impossible to taste the flavor of the meat, which is the entire brisket experience.  Minnie's brisket, while sometimes a little too dry (but generally excellent), earns a huge win when compared to Baby Blues.  

Minnie's sausage also wins.  This may be my personal preference only--I like Czech sausage, not the links that Baby Blues serves.  

Baby Blues may have a slight advantage on the ribs front.  The ribs (I tried both the Memphis style and the baby backs) are pretty good--juicy, though in smaller sizes and portions than Minnie's.  

The sides at Baby Blues are good.  Good cornbread and good creamed spinach.  The mac n cheese is identical to Minnie's, which makes me think they just use the same distributor.  

The service was also good.  This is sometimes a complaint of mine at Minnie's--they can be rude and dismissive, especially when busy.  At Baby Blues, the waiter and his young son (I think it was his son) were both very nice and asked what dishes I liked and didn't like--good form for a new business.

In the end, because quality of meat and preparation trump all other factors, Memphis Minnie's retains its spot on top.  Baby Blues isn't that far behind, though--and if you like ribs, I recommend it.
author: Damien W.

description:
I live up the hill and have been waiting for this location to turn into something for nearly two years. Thankfully, it finally has.... and it looks like the kind of business that will stick around. 

I say that still not having been in there, but we did have an opportunity for delivery service last night. (This after the mildly disappointing experience of trying to call for delivery on Thursday and learning there was a $20 minimum for delivery. Too steep for one person, easily achieved with more. FYI). 

We ordered the Blue Devil - are these guys Dukies? - and were quite pleased. Four meats and three sides (and an extra side of cornbread for my Southern girlfriend) for about $45 delivered, and we absolutely demolished the food. The meats - pulled pork, chicken, beef brisket, and ribs - were excellent, and the sides - mac and cheese, mashed potatoes, and creamed spinach - were all good, in that order of personal preference. Delivery was nice and fast and the overall experience was pleasant, and I can't wait to check this place out in person for even more bbq deliciousness.
author: Ian M.

description:
I've eaten here a lot, as it's about 4 blocks from where I live.  So, my three stars cover several 4, 3 and 2 star experiences.  Oh, also, I'm really lazy, and this also covers several delivery experiences I've had with them.

The pros:  good beer selection and they are really good for BBQ pork and ribs.  Also, mac and cheese is really really good.  They also do a nice banana pudding, and their smoked rice is tasty as well.

The cons: service all around has just been below par pretty consistently.  Also, I got a BBQ chicken sandwich there before which was partially raw ... twice.  When they cook their chicken properly, it's quite good, but I just don't want to risk a trip to the ER to enjoy my BBQ.

They used to be my first choice to call when I was too lazy to get my own food.
author: Joe S.

description:
I visited Baby Blues BBQ with and an open mind and an empty stomach, hoping to eat some great BBQ from a brand whose sister site is masturbated over by Guy Fieri of the Food Network.

Boy was I disappointed, firstly the big red sign above the door reads BBQ. So you would think there would be some element of smoke to the food. Alas not; the only element of smoke was the burnt smell from the two inept, lets say chefs in the loosest terms, incinerating everything in their path. Just like the "Dragon" in Dr. No.  They would have been better served using a flamethrower.  BBQ invokes the image of slow cooked, spicy, yet sweet food that melts in the mouth.  I have too many complaints, so lets list them for brevity.

1. XXX sauce (their signature) = over vinegary, habanera liquid served in a squeeze bottle with masking tape as a label.  Tasted just like Frank's RedHot original 
2. Sausage = $3.50 for an incinerated 5" offering that tasted like any generic sausage.
3. Ribs= to bad to mention, although tender, no seasoning, no spice, NO NOTHING.  Oh did I mention, more over cooked than Joan of Arc.
4. Beans = Blandy, Bland 
5. Mac and Cheese the only redeeming dish of the trip
6. Pulled pork = mediocre, they separated into  myofibrils, which is good, but again no flavor
7. Spinach = Good

I really wanted it to be great. I really wanted to support a local business, but I can't condone duping the public with crap, just like those infomercials.

So San Francisco you still lack a truly outstanding BQQ establishment. Bummer.!!!!
author: Dave C.

description: Best kept secret is their weekend brunch...I finally tried it today. The cream cheese filled french toast with organic fruit salad was amazing!! Usually I pop in there after work for my favorite pork belly salad, a side of cornbread, and a glass of wine. Surprisingly they have a superb selection. The Dylan, shrimp, and ribs are also crazy good and a great excuse to sample all the various sauces they offer. The staff there are knowledgeable and super friendly; they always make me feel like family when I come in. Plus, who doesn't love walking out of there smelling like smoked BBQ?
author: Maureen S.

description:
I admit I need to give the place another attempt as I have not yer tried everything they offer.  I did not like the Shrimp Po' Boy.  I prefer my po-boys on a soft roll, with crystal hot sauce, lettuce and mayo.  These were a bit too stylized.

The beef brisket was not as I had hoped.  It was just kinda watery, floppy and saucy.

What I need to try are the ribs. It may simply be that the ribs are what one is supposed to eat, and therefore my review is tenative and pending re-evaluation, but at least heed this as a warning, and instead opt for the ribs if you are on teetering on the edge of indecision.
author: christopher a.

description:
After wanting for some time to try this place we were disappointed. We tried three platters, the brisket, the pulled pork and the Memphis ribs. Of the three, the ribs were the best but still mediocre.  The brisket, despite appearing juicy, seemed to dry up after a couple chews in your mouth. The meat overall had little to no smokiness that you want in BBQ. The mac and cheese was good and had a nice hint of spice. The collard greens left us confused (why are they in a tomato sauce??). The mashed sweet potatoes were watery and way too sweet. The okra (also with tomatoes) was blah. The cornbread tasted good but was overcooked. The sweet tea was also too sweet. 

The portions are gigantic and on our visit the service was great.

There was a band playing the night we were there and although I did not mind the music it was quite loud so we had to scream at one another in order to converse. The music would have been better appreciated at a different venue.

We wanted to love you, but we left you still craving BBQ.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: Baby Blues is tasty, but as the other reviewers  note, this is not true BBQ.  There is no smoker -- ergo, it's not BBQ.  I've been to the SF location twice, and also went to the West Hollywood restaurant a few months back.  I've had the brisket, the pulled pork, the Memphis-style ribs and most of the side dishes (the mac n cheese, fried okra and creamed spinach are all solid).  The brisket and pulled pork are braised in Guinness, so it's tender, moist and has some depth -- but it has none of the smoky flavor that you would expect from BBQ.  I'm not sure how they do their ribs, but I imagine it's some sort of grill/oven combination.  Again, not BBQ.  It's not worth a special trip, but if you happen to be in Bernal Heights and want some grub in a mellow environment with decent service, Baby Blues will serve you well.
author: Andrew E.

description:
Since the word hit the street that this would be barbecue mere stumbling distance from my place, I've been counting the moments until I could stuff my face with carcass. Finally I got some take-out to tuck into with the missus. The food did not disappoint.

The pork ribs and brisket were delicious. Tender, flavorful, and moist. I fancied the XXX sauce and it was spicy and sweet and wonderful. By way of sides, we shared the mashed sweet potatoes, creamed spinach, pork n beans, and okra. They were all good, but the okra stood out as especially fantastic. And the corn bread was something special too.

I had a couple of gripes about the service on the pickup of my order (my bill was wrong and they forgot something I had to ask for), but I'll cut them some slack and hope it subsides as they figure out how to be a restaurant. My main complaint was that we ordered the key lime pie for dessert and the $5 portion was TEENY TINY. Tasty, but not a remotely respectable portion.

Ergo, I'll be going back, and probably often to partake of the wholesome taste of slaughter, and pass on dessert.
author: Nato G.

description: I went there twice.  the first time, the texas ribs were something out of a cave man feast -- a giant piece of beef with some rib bones that was charcoal black on the outside and juicy and tender on the inside, and so big that I couldn't finish it and had to take it home.  I went there a second time and the texas ribs were evenly cooked through and kind of boring, nothing like the first time.  If I could consistently get those cave man ribs, I'd go more often.
author: Paul M.

description:
Very tasty bbq. I had the ribs twice. I like the baby back more than memphis style, and their mac and cheese is really good. There was live music the tuesday night we went. Half a rack of ribs is $10-12.
Waaay better than Nate's bbq, my old stomping ground.
author: Julian M.

description:
Solid Solid Solid. Ribs fell of the bone. The baked beans were full of flavor....both BBQ sauces (regular and XXX) were yummmy, they have Blue Moon beer and the service was on it!
I will go back and will recommend this to friends. 

The restaurant is right on the corner and it is a great space. Its owned by a Mission resident so hopefully the neighborhood keeps them around for a while!!!

I'll be back
author: Jon C.

description:
I am more into fine dining but I was pleasantly surprised by baby blues.

Location: between mission and bernal heights... The crowd feels very local.

Parking: street parking was easy.

Staff: very friendly and helpful. I was debating between beef and pork so they gAve me two substantial samples to decide!

Food: not bad at all. I had the Cherokee spike composed of home made sausage (a bit salty but good) and tasty beef brisket. The sautéed okra was good. The corn bread was a delicious ...dessert lol ! Fluffy and sweet. 
My dish was quite filling and I couln't finish it. I think that I was stuffed by all the yummy fresh lemonade ( free refills).

I took one star off because I think it is a bit pricey for the type of food and location. I would almost pay the same price for fine dining bistro downtown. Eating out in SF is becoming expensive!
author: Anastasia M.

description:
We got the feed bag called "The Teaser" (feeds 6-8 folks) for five adults and there was still substantial leftovers.  

The best things here are really the Memphis-Style Ribs and the fixins (sides). These ribs are the probably the best I've had in SF yet. 

However, the chicken was only okay, and the baby back ribs were a little too charred. I would pass on the pulled pork and the brisket. Great sauces though, and plenty spicy.

The fixins were really stellar: lots of different kinds in the baked beans, great mac and cheese, and a decent cole slaw. The blues corn on the cob has some kind of cheese on it and was awesome. You could just eat the fixins and be plenty happy.

The corn bread, however, is so incredibly heavy and dense that I was expecting it to collapse upon itself and form a neutron star right there at the table.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Damn, these portions are hearty!

The moment you walk in, you're greeted by the intoxicating aroma of bbq... Each plate is served with 2 sides and cornbread. I had the brisket (YUM), sauteed okra (double YUM), and collard greens (triple YUM). I managed to finish all the brisket, but bitched out on the sides - don't judge me! 

With a wide variety of plates and sides, generous portions, AND delivery, I would definitely try it again!
author: Joanne T.

description:
Hipsters have no business running a BBQ joint.  Yuk!  The sides were were ok, but the meat has to be the main draw... and it sucked really bad.  You call that BRISKET????  That was crap.   ribs were DEEEEEERYYYYYY!!  The chicken  sucked ass.  Usually I would try a BBQ joint three for four times... but I can already tell this place aint going no where..  Should of stuck to plan A and drove to Gorilla in Pacifica.
PAAAAALEASE hire an expert!!!!!  Nice place though..
author: Demanding T.

description:
Went here the other night, and this place is just ok. The sauces were "ho-hum", a little too watered down for my taste. The collard greens were soggy, and didn't look fresh at all. I mean is it that hard to screw up vegetables??

Also, Mac & Cheese.... C'mon, were talking about some noodles in cheese sauce! This is not rocket science! Sure you have to add your own flavors to it to make it your own, but lets just start with the basics..... NOT over boiling the noodles, and then letting them sit inside of their now curdling cheese sauce concoction.

Service was pretty slow even though there were like 10 people in the joint. I guess if you don't actually know someone there, you automatically get shuffled into some service black hole. If your going to charge SF prices, shouldn't you at least get SF service quality??

The baby back ribs I had were cooked very good, at least they got this right. And my girlfriends chicken was very tasteful. This is why they are getting 2 stars. If they improve their side dishes (Don't get me started on the cornbread. Can you say "cornbread with a gallon of your finest brew, please!), and their service, this would be a very good place to go. Also, please take another look at the recipes for your BBQ sauces, decrease the water content by about 1/2 would be a good start.

Stand by for my comments about my next visit!
author: Aaron B.

description:
They were just written up in the Chronicle.  So those of you whining about the wait, not taking orders, being out of ribs:  they are new, getting good reviews, and weren't quite ready for the hoards of people. Be happy for a successful local biz.

We went Saturday and they were out of ribs - the latest batch needed another hour before they were ready.  So we grabbed some cornbread (it's amazing!) and headed across the street to El Rio and waited.  The people at Baby Blues are fab.  Atmosphere is great.  Loved the baby backs and the sides were divine - try the okra.  And if you like blue cheese, they put in in their mac.  The meal was $100ish for 4 people.  Seems pretty perfect to me.
author: Kelli R.

description:
I had a great experience at Baby Blues.  The food was great, the only thing that was a bit off was the beef brisket - It was overly moist and sort of tasteless, more like pot roast than brisket.  Other than that, everything else (the chicken, the beef ribs, the fixins) were delicious.  I highly recommend the mac n cheese, and the cornbread was really good.  

But more than the food, the service was fantastic.  I had reserved for a party of 25, as we were celebrating a birthday. I was a bit nervous about that, since the place isn't the biggest, but I didn't need to be. My boyfriend and I were the first to arrive, 10 minutes early, and they seated us right away.  No hassling about where the rest of our party was, or when we could expect them to arrive. Our party was served by two or three different people, all super friendly.  

No one in our party had been to this restaurant before, but all of them told me that I had made a good pick.  I would come back!
author: Cindy W.

description:
Living just a few short blocks away we have been going to Baby Blues since just after they opened.  Usually we go after we've exhausted our burrito/thai/vietnamese rations for the month, and it really is a comfortable place (excluding the too short benches) to hang out, and eat BBQ.  The staff is always nice, the clientele varied, sometimes there's live honky tonk playing (is that how you spell honky tonk?).  On average the food is always really good, though sometimes the tendency is to overcook some things (shrimp, chicken breast).  

Up until today I considered Baby Blues a pretty benign, non threat to my decency and pants size, because you had to make the choice to go there, and because I pass it pretty often while I'm jogging, and that puts it all in check because I'm able to feel at that very moment how hard it is to say good bye to juicy, tangy, fatty BBQ.  But, today for lunch we had the pulled pork (boyfriends) and chicken (mine) sandwiches and collard greens, and they were DELIVERED TO US!  That's right folks, BBQ delivery, which means that I'll either have to up the jogging (ya, right) or hide all phones in the toilet tank and force myself to eat vegetables and quinoa from our fridge....hard to do when a plate of ribs is just 20 min. (ya, they're fast too) away, and you can eat your messy, smeary, delicious, gluttonous meal in the privacy of your own home.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
More like a 4.5

After being a bit disappointed from the Chronicle's review of Bo's Barbecue in Lafayette, I decided to give the food critics at the Chron another try when it came to barbecue.  Reading the review, I felt a slight bit an elitist foodie's disdain.  That was in contrast to the review for Bo's where it was quite glowing, so glowing that Bo's is on the Chronicle 100.  Perhaps this place would be good because the Chronicle didn't absolutely love this place.

The pulled pork was among the best I have ever had.  Slow cooked in Guinness then smoked for 12 hours the flavors of the spices fully penetrated the meat.  I'm pretty sure one of my friends from North Caroline would really appreciate the pulled pork.

I wasn't too crazy about their sauces, which were vinegar based.  The mild tasted too mild and the spicy was very hot.  The apple cider vinegar complemented the pulled pork best.  Ribs were a little bit overdone, but the meat fell right of the bone.  

The okra was good, but not a taste I was expecting.  Good food, highly recommended.
author: Kenny L.

description:
I had been here twice before and found things to be okay but this week's "dinner" will be the last visit. 

- Cold chicken (yes, folks it's cooked well in advance of dinnertime. The waiter revealed after I questioned when it was cooked)
- 85 degrees in the restaurant and no ventilation
- No manager working that night (who is running this place?)
- No offer to compensate for the cold and dry chicken
- Sent email via web site before posting here and no response.

Good luck Baby Blues.
author: hercule p.

description:
Errr, I think it said BBQ above the door. Hang on a sec, let me go look.....

Yep. It says BBQ.

So, where's the BBQ? I saw an oven. I saw a grill. Surely they're not slow cooking meat in the oven, then char-grilling it and calling it BBQ? Because that's how it tastes.

Nice mac'n'chee though and reasonable creamed spinach. Maybe they should call themselves Baby Blues Southern Sides.
author: Neil S.

description:
I can't give this place a lower review. I'm not reviewing the food but the customer service and communication. On Monday the phone message said  it would be for sure open on Tuesday. So a bunch of us went to have a going away dinner there. Not open. On Tuesday the message said it would be open on Friday the 26. Apparently it was. However on Monday at 5:45 all there was was a gentleman on his harley in the restaurant space. They have tried to pass off the problem as a miscommunication with the Chronicle review. BS. This place just has incredibly poor customer service and communication skills. 
Truly San Francisco doesn't need a restaurant like this.
author: Joe D.

description:
Baby Blue's BBQ is open. The snafus have been dealt with and Baby Blues is ready to serve you all the best BBQ I've ever had. Yes, I am a  good friend of the owner. For those of you who have tried to enjoy the wonderful ribs, greens, beans, coleslaw, corn bread... mmmm corn bread... and have gone by to find Baby Blue's closed, your wait is over. 

Believe what the other reviewers have stated here. Baby Blue's has taken the best of many BBQ styles and combined only the best of those styles for your dining pleasure. So, go on, give it a try. Baby Blue's BBQ will keep you coming back for more.

As I said, I am bias. Just wrote this to let people know the wait is over. I'll be there Saturday evening with a gang of friends. That have had to listen to me go on for weeks now about how good it is.

If this review is inappropriate, please, remove it. 

See you there 1/17/09,
Corey
author: Dell S.

description:
When we walked in it didn't smell like BBQ at all -- a bad sign. Later when we got our food our suspicions were confirmed as it was obvious that our ribs were cooked a while earlier and simply heated up. I realize that ribs take a long time to cook but I have seen other restaurants manage this more effectively either through pre-baking the ribs and then grilling to order or keeping a steady stream of fresh ribs coming off the grill. Perhaps it was bad timing as we came for an early dinner around 5pm.

While the ribs would probably be 4+ stars if they were fresh, the sides were terrible. All of them. I ate some congealed, bland mac and cheese with below average coleslaw and cornbread. The cornbread was served cold with no butter. Weak. My quest for great BBQ in San Francisco continues.
author: Aaron V.

description:
By way of background, I am a BBQ fanatic.  I moved to the Bay Area five years ago from a state that prides itself on pulled pork, and have been searching for a truly suitable option around here since then.

Baby Blues is the only BBQ joint in the Bay Area that meets my standards. 

Check out their ribs... new recipe; fall-off-the-bone goodness.  Definitely the best beef rib around.
author: Ben A.

description: I went to BB's last night...It was a great choice!  I had a tasty Blue Moon, along with the shrimp Po Boy sandwich....delightfulll!!!  As if I weren't full enough, I saw the Mac n cheese go by and ordered that too......I was complete ;}  Loved the lighting.... the patrons and staff were friendly too.  Parking was easy.  Yelp, I would def go there again....
author: Alisa F.

description:
Got take-out tonight.  Big Blue Platter w/ 3 meats & 2 fixin's - got double pulled pork, beef brisket, creamed spinach & mac 'n cheese.  My husband and I grew up in the south (he in Little Rock and I in Austin), so we have high expectations for bbq meats.  The pulled pork was nice and tender but lacking in flavor, definitely needed the sauce. The hot hot sauce was nearing too hot.  The vinegar sauce was great on the pork and the other bbq sauce they gave us was pretty tasty.  

The beef brisket was interesting.  Coming from Texas, I'm accustomed to sliced brisket, they had it pulled - strange.  Flavor was alright but tasted like it hadn't been slow roasted for long enough, my man said "it needed more smoke."  

Regarding the sides...we didn't get our cornbread.  I was upset to find this out at home, particularly since Yelp reviews spoke highly of it.  The creamed spinach was horrible; tough, chewy, unseasoned, just not well prepared at all.  The mac 'n cheese however was delicious.  

In conclusion...they have Shiner Bock on tap - good enough for me to go back.
author: Mandi C.

description:
i recently had a not so great experience with their texas beef ribs.  this was the 1st of over 10 times going that i have had a negative experience so i will consider it an anomaly and not deduct any stars.

decent service and great bbq food.  i usually get the texas style beef rib with cornbread and the corn on the cob with mexican cheese/lime.  when you see this rib you think to yourself yabba dabba doooooo!!!!  this is one big arse flintstone rib, but it is extremely tender and flavorful.  i usually have the mild sauce so that i can still have feeling in my lips afterward and the molasses mixed together for dipping.  i go in without eating dinner the night before, a small but light breakfast then no food for the next 3 days after the meal.  even though i am full, i cannot bring myself to stop.

the other stuff in this place is great too, the jumbo prawns, other ribs et al.

i think i even had some dessert here once, banana pudding possibly?  it was great, but seriously... i was way too full to enjoy it.
author: Wayne L.

description:
